content.raw:
It passes in real-vrc with nvidia (which probably is the fastest of our testing machines) in precise: 
[gazebo-default-devel-precise-amd64-gpu-nvidia](http://build.osrfoundation.org/view/gazebo/job/gazebo-default-devel-precise-amd64-gpu-nvidia/)

It looks like a problem with computing time in all cases.
content.html:
It passes in real-vrc with nvidia (which probably is the fastest of our testing machines) in precise: gazebo-default-devel-precise-amd64-gpu-nvidia

It looks like a problem with computing time in all cases.

content.raw:
But sometimes real-vrc also suffers from this problem:

[gazebo-default-BTrelease-precise-amd64](http://build.osrfoundation.org/view/gazebo/job/gazebo-default-BTrelease-precise-amd64/44/consoleFull)
```
#!

93: /var/lib/jenkins/workspace/gazebo-default-BTrelease-precise-amd64/gazebo/test/regression/transport_stress.cc:205: Failure
93: Expected: (static_cast<unsigned int>(pubDiff.nsec)) < ((g_localPublishMessageCount * nodes.size()) * 1500), actual: 376772334 vs 30000000
93: [1;32mMsg[0m Time to publish 20000 = 16 376772334
93: [1;32mMsg[0m Time to receive 40000000 = 22 145414711
```
content.html:
But sometimes real-vrc also suffers from this problem:

gazebo-default-BTrelease-precise-amd64

93: /var/lib/jenkins/workspace/gazebo-default-BTrelease-precise-amd64/gazebo/test/regression/transport_stress.cc:205: Failure
93: Expected: (static_cast<unsigned int>(pubDiff.nsec)) < ((g_localPublishMessageCount * nodes.size()) * 1500), actual: 376772334 vs 30000000
93: [1;32mMsg[0m Time to publish 20000 = 16 376772334
93: [1;32mMsg[0m Time to receive 40000000 = 22 145414711

content.raw:
We should review if this performance limits are valid or are too strict for not so fast machines.

BTW, we should start thinking on moving performance test to its own category and track them in a different way than unit and system tests. What should be consider a fail from a performance point of view it is relative.
content.html:
We should review if this performance limits are valid or are too strict for not so fast machines.

BTW, we should start thinking on moving performance test to its own category and track them in a different way than unit and system tests. What should be consider a fail from a performance point of view it is relative.

content.raw:
I was just watching top while running the transport_stress test, and it can require up to 1.5 GB of memory. I'm guessing that may be a factor in the test failures. Also, I've seen some of the tests [timeout even after reaching nearly the end of the test](http://build.osrfoundation.org/job/gazebo-default-devel-precise-amd64/302/consoleFull). I caught a backtrace of one of these hangs in my virtual machine (so take with a grain of salt):

content.html:
I was just watching top while running the transport_stress test, and it can require up to 1.5 GB of memory. I'm guessing that may be a factor in the test failures. Also, I've seen some of the tests timeout even after reaching nearly the end of the test. I caught a backtrace of one of these hangs in my virtual machine (so take with a grain of salt):

content.raw:
Great job @scpeters ! Dmesg in our master machine shows:

```
[8978893.740300] Out of memory: Kill process 8021 (transport_stres) score 587 or sacrifice child
[8978893.740326] Killed process 8021 (transport_stres) total-vm:2524580kB, anon-rss:1483740kB, file-rss:0kB
```

Seems like the problem is the big amounts of memory needed to run the transport stress test. Let's give it a look and see if:

* There is a memory leak
* We can transform this test to not to consume this amount of memory.
content.html:
Great job @scpeters ! Dmesg in our master machine shows:

[8978893.740300] Out of memory: Kill process 8021 (transport_stres) score 587 or sacrifice child
[8978893.740326] Killed process 8021 (transport_stres) total-vm:2524580kB, anon-rss:1483740kB, file-rss:0kB

Seems like the problem is the big amounts of memory needed to run the transport stress test. Let's give it a look and see if:

  • There is a memory leak
  • We can transform this test to not to consume this amount of memory.

content.raw:
Big numbers in the test. In my local testing runs:

* 2000 nodes publishing 10 times ~ 1.7Gb used
* 1000 nodes publishing 10 times ~ 0.4Gb used
* 2000 nodes publishing 5 times ~ 0.8Gb used

It would be nice to know what was the origin of this test (the regression issue) to see how can be reduced. If unknown, I would go for split the test in two: one with 2k nodes publishing around 5 times, another with 1k nodes publishing 10 times.
content.html:
Big numbers in the test. In my local testing runs:

  • 2000 nodes publishing 10 times ~ 1.7Gb used
  • 1000 nodes publishing 10 times ~ 0.4Gb used
  • 2000 nodes publishing 5 times ~ 0.8Gb used

It would be nice to know what was the origin of this test (the regression issue) to see how can be reduced. If unknown, I would go for split the test in two: one with 2k nodes publishing around 5 times, another with 1k nodes publishing 10 times.

content.raw:
It was introduced in pull request #371 and appears to be related to performance. Here's one of my comments in that pull request about the test:
~~~
I ran the transport_stress test with 100 messages on default, and it
took about 3 ms / message. With this branch I ran 1 million messages
in 9.2 seconds, which is about 9 microseconds / message, about 300
times faster.
~~~
I'm guessing that the key part is the time per message, so let's ask @nkoenig if we can scale down the total number of messages, while still expecting the same time per message. 1000 nodes publishing 10 times looks good to me, since it requires much less memory.
content.html:
It was introduced in pull request #371 and appears to be related to performance. Here's one of my comments in that pull request about the test:

I ran the transport_stress test with 100 messages on default, and it
took about 3 ms / message. With this branch I ran 1 million messages
in 9.2 seconds, which is about 9 microseconds / message, about 300
times faster.

I'm guessing that the key part is the time per message, so let's ask @nkoenig if we can scale down the total number of messages, while still expecting the same time per message. 1000 nodes publishing 10 times looks good to me, since it requires much less memory.

content.raw: We could test the system to see how much RAM is available and choose between the full test or a scaled back version.
content.html: We could test the system to see how much RAM is available and choose between the full test or a scaled back version.

content.raw:
It would solve our problem but then we will have a mutable performance test depending on operative system conditions (free RAM available), which can vary from run to run and could not be useful to compare results.

Check for free RAM and skip the test if it can not be run sounds a bit more reliable to me. What do you think?
content.html:
It would solve our problem but then we will have a mutable performance test depending on operative system conditions (free RAM available), which can vary from run to run and could not be useful to compare results.

Check for free RAM and skip the test if it can not be run sounds a bit more reliable to me. What do you think?

content.raw: We should try it in a branch and run on gazebo-any a few times. The proof's in the pudding.
content.html: We should try it in a branch and run on gazebo-any a few times. The proof's in the pudding.

content.raw:
Thinking a bit more about it I would be happy with something like:

* Provide a cmake variable, something like LOW_MEM_TESTING, which can activate a scaled version of the tests which need a lot of RAM.
* Tests will check how much memory is currently available and if not enough, it will skip the test.

This way we can control when original version or scaled is run and even avoid the run when the memory is not enough. I will implement this version unless somebody has a better idea.
content.html:
Thinking a bit more about it I would be happy with something like:

  • Provide a cmake variable, something like LOW_MEM_TESTING, which can activate a scaled version of the tests which need a lot of RAM.
  • Tests will check how much memory is currently available and if not enough, it will skip the test.

This way we can control when original version or scaled is run and even avoid the run when the memory is not enough. I will implement this version unless somebody has a better idea.

content.raw: Pull request #483 and Pull request #484 should implement the proposed solution.
content.html: Pull request #483 and Pull request #484 should implement the proposed solution.
